title: CV
text:
Current Research Role
Graduate Student Researcher
August 2023-Present
\(\textbf{University of California, Berkeley,}\) Berkeley, CA

Independently evaluated the predictive performance of different administrative data sources to forecast fatal overdoses at the neighborhood level with machine learning in R. Performed analysis in collaboration with research teams at Brown and New York University within the context of the PROVIDENT randomized control trial in Rhode Island (NIH R01 DA046620). Established an accessible template for non-technical stakeholders to utilize machine learning to forecast fatal overdoses to allocate overdose prevention resources.
Investigating the effect of acute community violence on maternal and infant health and racial/ethnic health disparities as part of NIH R01 HD098138. Processing data for over 6 million study individuals over more than a decade. Developing time series models for exposure assessment and implementing novel targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) methods for causal inference.

title: John Halifax
text: I’m John Halifax, a PhD student in Epidemiology at UC Berkeley. I am passionate about social epidemiology, and aim to be a scholar with a deep and versatile biostatistical toolkit addressing socio-medical questions about vulnerable populations.
